metadata.title: Nano-ZnO priming induces salt tolerance by promoting photosynthetic carbon assimilation in wheat

sections.text:

Nano-ZnO priming induces salt tolerance by promoting photosynthetic carbon assimilation in wheat
Zongshuai Wang, Hui Li, Xiangnan Li, Caiyun Xin, Jisheng Si, Shengdong Li, Yujie Li, Xinxin Zheng, Huawei Li, Xiuhua Wei, Zhiwei Zhang, Lingan Kong & Fahong Wang

Nano-ZnO priming induces salt tolerance by promoting photosynthetic carbon

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
High salt seriously reduces plant growth in wheat by depressing photosynthetic carbon assimilation. In this study, wheat plants were firstly primed with nano-ZnO (50 mg L-1), and after 20-day recovery the plants were then exposed to a 10-day salt stress (200 mM NaCl). The nano-ZnO priming significantly reduced Na concentration and increased leaf water potential under salt stress. In relation to the non-primed plants, the nano-ZnO primed plants possessed more effective oxygen scavenging system as exemplified by the enhanced activities of SOD, APX and CAT, leading to a better maintenance in homeostasis of ROS production under salt stress. The nano-ZnO priming benefited the tolerance of photosynthetic apparatus to subsequent salt stress, which was mainly due to the enhanced trapped energy flux and electron transport flux. The nano-ZnO priming increased the activities of phosphoglucomutase and cytoplasmic invertase, which promoted the sucrose biosynthesis in leaves under salt stress. In addition, the nano-ZnO primed plants had higher shoot dry weight than the non-primed plants under salt stress. Collectively, nano-ZnO priming activated the antioxidant system to depress the oxidative burst and enhanced the efficiency of photosynthetic electron transport and sucrose biosynthesis in leaves under salt stress, hereby improved the salt tolerance in wheat.
Keywords: chlorophyll fluorescence; carbohydrate metabolism; salinity; Triticum aestivum; Zinc Oxide

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Soil salinity is a critical problem, influencing more than 800 million hectares of land in the world, and it accounts for more than 6% of the global land mass (Munns and Tester 2008). Wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) generally shows a moderate tolerance to salinity. The grain
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
yield loss exceeds 60% due to soil salinity in wheat (El-Hendawy et al. 2017). The salt-induced loss of grain yield is related to the adverse effects of excess salts on photosynthesis, carbohydrate metabolism and plant water status (Kerepesi et al. 1998; Mehta et al. 2010; Sun et al. 2016). Photosynthesis is the primary metabolic sink to support plant growth, converting light energy into ATP and redox equivalents (Brestic et al. 2012; Zivcak et al. 2013; Brestic et al. 2014). Photosynthetic apparatus, especially the photosynthetic electron transport system is highly sensitive to salt stress (Munns and Tester. 2008; Kalaji et al. 2017). High salt results in modulations in expression of photosynthetic proteins in chloroplasts, depressing functioning of the photosystems (PS) (Zhao et al. 2013). The processes of light energy trapping by the antenna of PS I and PS II and charge separation in reaction centres (RCs) are easily disturbed by salt stress, since the chlorophyll antenna complexes trap more energy than the capacity of biochemical procession in RCs, hence leading to accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Kaur et al. 2018).
Several strategies have been developed to enhance the salt tolerance in plants. It has been
well documented that an early exposure to a moderate stressor can result in a higher tolerance to the subsequent stress in various plant species (Bruce et al. 2007; Wang et al. 2017). Also, the pretreatment with a low level of NaCl can induce a higher salt tolerance, which is referred to as salt acclimation (Janda et al. 2016; Wang et al. 2017). Our previous study showed that the salt acclimation induced salt tolerance in wheat by driving the antioxidant systems to protect photosynthetic electron transport and maintaining a better water status (Wang et al. 2017).
Nanoparticles (NPs) is a kind of particulate nanomaterial with at least one dimension in
the nanoscale (1-100 nm) (Wang et al. 2015). Some kinds of NPs can be easily uptaken, transported, and accumulated in plant organs, which regulate the physiological and biochemical processes, hence affecting plant growth and development, such as silicon nanoparticle and magnesium nanoparticle (Rastogi et al. 2017). Influence of NPs can be
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
determined by their size, reactivity, chemical structure and surface coating (Tripathi et al. 2017b). As metal ions, NPs react with sulfhydryl and carboxyl groups of proteins, and thus alter the activities of enzymes (Shaw et al. 2014). Zinc (Zn) is an essential micronutrient for chloroplast development and chlorophyll synthesis in plants (Ahmad et al. 2017). Nano-ZnO is one of the most popular NPs, which has been widely applied in medicines, pigments, batteries and agriculture (Ju-Nam and Lead 2008). However, both positive and negative influences of nano-ZnO on plant growth have been found in several plant species (Du et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Abdel Latef et al. 2016). The impact of nano-ZnO on plant depends its size, concentration, and exposure methodology (Rastogi et al. 2017). For instance, the exposure to nano-ZnO (1000 mg L-1) caused oxidative stress and significantly reduced the root length at early growing stages in rice (Boonyanitipong et al. 2011). Recently, it has been reported that nano-ZnO foliar spray combined with use of biochar could improve the plant growth and decrease the cadmium accumulation in rice (Ali et al. 2019). Nano-ZnO exposure inhibited activities of the ascorbate-glutathione cycle (AsA-GSH), hence increasing H2O2 accumulation and lipid peroxidation (Tripathi et al. 2017a). In lupine (Lupinus termis), nano-ZnO priming (60 mg L-1) enhanced salt tolerance by decreasing the concentrations of malondialdehyde (MDA) and Na+ (Abdel Latef et al. 2016).
Fast chlorophyll a fluorescence induction curve can be used to test the photosynthetic
electron transport as influenced by salt stress (Kalaji et al. 2018). In the present study, wheat plants were firstly primed with nano-ZnO (50 mg L-1), and after a 20-d recovery the plants were exposed to a 10-d salt stress treatment (200 mM NaCl). The efficiency of photosynthetic electron transport system and oxygen scavenging system, plant water status and activities of key carbohydrate metabolism enzyme following ZnO priming and salt treatment were investigated. It was hypothesized that: (1) the nano-ZnO priming could improve the salt tolerance of wheat plants; (2) the nano-ZnO priming could drive the antioxidant system to protect photosynthetic carbon assimilation in wheat under salt stress.
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt

sections.heading: Experimental design and materials
sections.text:
Winter wheat (Triticum aestivum L. cv. Yannong19) was used in a pot experiment in a climate-controlled glasshouse from February to May 2018. Selected wheat seeds were sown in plastic pots (20 cm in height and 15 cm in diameter) filled with 3.5 kg of sandy loam. Before filling the pots, the soil was sieved by passing through a 5 mm mesh and pre-mixed with 2 g N, 1 g P2O5 and 1.2 g K2O per pot. No more fertilizer was added during the experiment. The photosynthetic active radiation (12 h photoperiod) was 500 μmol m-2 s-1. The temperature was 28/20 °C in the day/night. Eight seeds were sown in each pot, and four seedlings were retained after thinning. Treatments At four-leaf stage, half of wheat plants were primed with nano-ZnO by adding 50 mg L-1 ZnO NPs (NPs < 50 nm) suspension to the pots, at a rate of 50 mg kg-1. The nano-ZnO was purchased from DK Nano Technology Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China) with a purity of 99.5%. The ZnO nanorods size was selected depending on the previous study (Abdel Latef et al. 2016). The nano-ZnO concentration was selected according to the preliminary experiment. In the preliminary experiment, five concentrations of ZnO NPs (10, 20, 50, 100, 500 mg L-1) were applied to wheat 4-leaf seedlings under salt treatment (200 mM NaCl), the optimal concentration of ZnO NPs was selected based on the dry matter and length of root and shoot of wheat seedlings. Twenty days after the nano-ZnO priming, half of the primed plants and non-primed plants were exposed to the salt treatment by irrigating with a solution containing 200 mM NaCl for ten days. The concentration of NaCl has been standardized with the wheat plants. The remaining pots were irrigated with water as the control. Thus, four treatments were established: C, the non-stress control; S, the salt treatment; ZnO, the nano-ZnO priming without salt treatment; and ZnO+S, the nano-ZnO priming plus salt treatment. The experiment was a randomized block design, with three replicates for each treatment. Each replication
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
consisted of three pots. The experimental conditions for the wheat plants after nano-ZnO priming and salt treatment were same as those before. One pot from each replication was used for measurements of dry weights of shoot and root, shoot height and root length after salt treatment. Leaf Na concentration For Na concentration measurement, 100 mg leaf sample was incubated in 5 ml concentrated sulphuric acid to completely digested with 30% H2O2 as catalyst. The digestive solution was transferred to 50 ml volumetric flask to constant volume and diluted before test with a TAS 986 atomic absorption spectrophotometer (Beijing Purkinje General Instrument, Beijing, China). Measurements of H2O2 concentration and antioxidant enzyme activities The H2O2 concentration was measured by monitoring the absorbance of titanium peroxide complex at 410 nm (Moloi et al. 2006). The activities of APX and SOD in leaves were measured following our previous methods (Tan et al. 2008). APX activity was determined by monitoring the decrease at 290 nm, and the activity of SOD was measured by monitoring the inhibition of photochemical reduction of nitro blue tetrazolium (NBT). Catalase (CAT) activity was determined spectrophotometrically following H2O2 consumption at 240 nm (Bailly et al. 1996). Protein content in the leaf was determined according to the method of Bradford (1976). Measurements of photosynthetic rate and chlorophyll concentration After the salt treatment, photosynthetic rate (Pn), stomatal conductance (gs), and transpiration rate (Tr) of the latest fully expanded leaves were measured with a portable photosynthesis system (Li-6400, Li-Cor, NE, USA) at a CO2 concentration of 400 μmol mol-1, with a photosynthetically active radiation of 1200 μmolm-2 s-1. The cuvette temperature was set at 25 °C. During each measurement, three leaves were taken from each of three replicates of individual treatments. The chlorophyll concentration was measured non-destructively with a
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
SPAD 502 Chlorophyll meter (Soil Plant Analysis Development, Minolta, Japan) on the same leaf as for the gas exchange analysis. For each measurement, often SPAD values were averaged as the chlorophyll concentration of the latest fully expanded leaf. Chlorophyll a fluorescence Fast chlorophyll a fluorescence induction curve (OJIP curve) was measured with the same leaves as for the gas exchange measurement after the salt treatment and was analyzed using Plant Efficiency Analyzer (Pocket-PEA, Hansatech, Norfolk, UK). Before measuring, thirty minutes of dark adaption of the leaves was needed. The collected data were processed by the program PEA Plus 1.04. The parameters selected for this study are presented in Table 1. The quantum yield of PSII photochemistry (ФII), non-photochemical quenching (ФNPQ), and other unregulated losses (ФNO) were taken using a MultispeQ (Beta version, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, US). The MultispeQ is developed for the rapid capture fluorescence parameters during steady-state illumination using a procedure that obviates the need for extensive pre-acclimation to the leaf chamber light conditions (Kuhlgert et al. 2016). Leaf water potential After the measurements of gas exchange and chlorophyll a fluorescence, the same leaf was used to determine the midday leaf water potential (Ψl) with a pressure chamber (Soil Moisture Equipment, Santa Barbara, Ca, USA). Activity of carbohydrate enzymes The protein extraction and measurements of carbohydrate enzyme activities were measured following the methods of Jammer et al. (2015). The UDP-glucose pyrophorylase (UGPase), glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PDH), phosphoglucomutase (PGM) and phosphoglucoisomerase (PGI) was assessed in the endpoint assays, while the invertases (cytoplasmic invertase; vacuolar invertase and cell wall invertase) was determined in kinetic enzyme assays (Gasperl et al. 2015; Jammer et al. 2015). The analysis of enzyme activities for each sample were run in triplicate with blanks. The specific enzyme activity was calculated
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
within the linear range of substrate conversion and expressed in nkatmg-1protein (Jammer et al. 2015). Statistical analysis All data were subjected to the one-way ANOVA to determine the significant differences among treatments with the software of SPSS (Ver. 19.0 SPSS, Chicago, IL, USA). Energy pipeline leaf model of phenomenological fluxes (per cross-section, CS) was applied with the Biolyzer 3.0software (Bioenergetics Lab, Geneva, Switzerland).

sections.heading: Results
sections.text:
Dry weights of shoot and root, shoot height and root length High salt caused significant reductions by 19 %-35 % in dry weights of shoot and root, shoot height and root length, compared with the non-stress control (Table 2). The nano-ZnO priming increased significantly the shoot dry weight (by 16%), shoot height (by 11%) and root length (by 13%) in wheat seedlings under salt stress, compared with non-priming treatment. The nano-ZnO priming had no significant effect on root dry weight under salt stress and normal condition. Na concentration and leaf water potential The leaf Na concentration was 9-fold higher in salt stressed plants, compared with the control (Figure 1). However, nano-ZnO primed plants had significantly lower Na concentration than non-primed plants when exposed to salt stress. The salt treatment significantly reduced by 59% the leaf water potential (Ψl) compared with the control. Under salt stress, the nano-ZnO primed plants had relatively higher Ψl than non-primed plants. H2O2 concentration and antioxidant enzymes The H2O2 concentration in leaf was significantly increased by 95.4% under salt treatment (Figure 2). The nano-ZnO primed plants possessed significantly lower H2O2 concentration, compared with non-primed plants under salt stress. The SOD activity was enhanced by salt
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
treatment compared with the control. The nano-ZnO primed plant had significantly higher SOD activity in leaf than non-primed plants. A similar trend was found in APX activity. In addition, the highest CAT activity was found in ZnO+S plants among four treatments. Gas exchange and chlorophyll concentration The Pn and chlorophyll concentration (SPAD) of the latest fully expanded leaf was significantly depressed by salt treatment (Figure 3). Under salt stress, the Pn was significantly higher in nano-ZnO primed plants than that in non-primed plants. However, there was not significant difference in SPAD between nano-ZnO primed and non-primed plants when exposed to salt stress. The lowest gs and Tr were found in salt treatment among these four treatments. Under salt stress, nano-ZnO primed plants had significantly higher gs and Tr than the non-primed plants. Chl a fluorescence transient The maximum quantum yield of PS II (Fv/Fm) was reduced by 23% in the salt treatment, compared with the control (Figure 4). The nano-ZnO priming had no significant effect on Fv/Fm under non-stress condition; however, the primed plants had significantly higher Fv/Fm than the non-primed plants under salt stress. The OJIP test parameters were further analyzed based on the chlorophyll a fluorescence rise transients (Table 1). Under non-stress condition, the maximum quantum yield for primary photochemistry (φPO) was not affected by the priming with nano-ZnO; however, the nano-ZnO primed plants had a higher φPO than the non-primed plants under salt stress. It should be noted that the highest value of probability that an electron moves further than QA (ψEO) was found in C plants, followed by S and ZnO plants, while the lowest one was in ZnO+S. The nano-ZnO priming decreased the quantum yield for electron transport (ET) (φEO) in wheat plants under non-stress condition, whereas, ZnO priming showed no significant effect on φEO in plants exposed to soil salinity. In addition, the quantum yield for reduction of end electron acceptors at the PSI acceptor side (RE) (φRO) was significantly decreased by salt treatment, but it was not affected by the priming with
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
nano-ZnO.
The relative values of the derived parameters from the OJIP curves were showed in
Figure 4 and summarized by means of energy pipeline leaf model of phenomenological fluxes (per cross-section, CS) as presented in Figure 5. The relative value of different parameters was indicated by the size of arrows with various colors. It was found that the energy absorbed per excited cross section (CSm) (ABS/CSm) was significantly reduced by salt stress, compared with the control. However, no significant difference was observed among treatments of C, ZnO and ZnO+S. The non-photochemical quenching per CSm (DIo/CSm) was all increased by S, ZnO and ZnO+S, compared with C; and the highest DIo/CSm was in ZnO+S. The trapped energy flux per CSm (TRO/CSm) was similar in C, ZnO and ZnO+S treatments, while it was significantly lower in S treatment. A similar trend was observed in electron transport flux per CS (ETo/CSm) and PS I acceptor per CS (REO/CSm) among these four treatments. In addition, the number of active reaction centre (RCs) in PS II cross-section (shown by open circles in Figure 5) was significantly reduced by salt stress. A relatively higher number of active RCs was found in the nano-ZnO primed plants, compared with non-primed plants under salt stress.
The quantum yield of PSII photochemistry (ФII) was remarkably reduced by salt
treatment, compared with the control (Figure 6). However, the salt-induced decrease in ФII was lower in primed plants than that in non-primed plants. A contrary trend was found for the quantum yield of non-photochemical quenching (ФNPQ): The S plants had the highest ФNPQ, followed by ZnO and ZnO+S plants, and the lowest ФNPQ was in C plants. Compared with the control, the quantum yield of other unregulated (non-photochemical) losses (ФNO) was significantly decreased by salt stress; whereas, it was not affected by the single nano-ZnO priming (ZnO). Activity of carbohydrate enzymes The pathway of primary carbohydrate metabolism in wheat leaf was presented in Figure 7.
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
The key carbohydrate enzymes include UDP-glucose pyrophorylase (UGPase), glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PDH), phosphoglucomutase (PGM) and phosphoglucoisomerase (PGI). Compared with the control, UGPase activity was enhanced significantly by nano-ZnO priming; however, it was not affected by salt treatment. In addition, no significant difference in UGPase activity was found between S and ZnO+S. The nano-ZnO primed plants had significantly higher PGM activity than the non-primed plants. It was notable that compared with the control, the activity of PGI was increased by nano-ZnO priming under normal condition, but it was decreased by nano-ZnO priming under salt stress. The G6PDH activity was similar among C, S and ZnO treatments, while the highest G6PDH activity was found in ZnO+S treatment.
Compared with the control, the activity of cytoplasmic invertase (cytInv) was reduced by
nano-ZnO priming; however, the primed plants had significantly higher activity of cytInv than the non-primed plants under salt stress (Figure 8). Also, the activity of vacuolar invertase (vacInv) was decreased by salt treatment. There was no significant difference in vacInv activity between S and ZnO+S plants. In addition, the activity of cell wall invertase (cwInv) was significantly enhanced by nano-ZnO priming under non-stress and salt stress conditions. Proline and total soluble sugar Salt stress significantly increased by 55 % the proline concentration while decreased by 15% the total soluble sugar (TSS) concentration in leaf (Figure 9). The nano-ZnO priming significantly enhanced the proline concentration under both non-salt and salt conditions. Under salt stress, the nano-ZnO priming significantly enhanced the leaf TSS concentration, compared with the control.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
High salt concentrations in soil cause a decrease in water potential, which affects water availability (Jakab et al. 2005). The salt-induced osmotic stress remarkably reduces water
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
absorption of roots and changes leaf water status in wheat (Rahnama et al. 2010). In the present study, salt stress resulted in an obvious increase in Na concentration and depressed the shoot and root growth in wheat. A reduction of leaf water potential (Ψl) was also found in wheat plants exposed to salt stress. Under salt stress, the nano-ZnO primed plants had significantly lower Na concentration and higher Ψl in leaf, compared with the non-primed plants. This indicated that the salt-induced osmotic stress was alleviated by nano-ZnO priming. In addition, the leaf proline concentration was enhanced by nano-ZnO priming, compared with the control under salt stress. It might be related to the significant increase in organic solutes, such as soluble sugars (Abdel Latef et al. 2016). In addition, the nano-ZnO priming mitigated the toxicity of Na by decreasing the Na accumulation in leaves, which is important for salt tolerance in wheat. Besides, the adverse effect of salt stress on root growth in wheat was alleviated by the nano-ZnO priming.
In addition to osmotic stress and ionic toxicity, salt stress also causes an oxidative stress,
mediated by ROS (Ahmad et al. 2018). The H2O2 concentration observed in salt stressed plants correlated with an increase in SOD activity as well as a decrease in CAT activity (Ahmad et al. 2010). In scavenging ROS, SOD catalyzes the disproportionation of singlet oxygen (1O2) generated from chloroplast electron transport chains and produces H2O2 (Keunen et al. 2013). Then CAT decomposes H2O2 to H2O and O2, together with APX (Keunen et al. 2013). The nano-ZnO priming significantly increased the activities of all these antioxidant enzymes, which obviously enhanced the ROS scavenging capacity in wheat leaves. This agrees with the early results that redox homeostasis is maintained with an activated oxygen scavenging system in nano-ZnO pretreated plants (Abdel Latef et al. 2016). In addition, zinc application was also reported to mitigate the adverse effects of salt stress through regulating the antioxidant enzymes in mustard (Ahmad et al. 2017).
In this study, a rapid reduction in Pn and SPAD of the latest fully expanded leaves in
wheat was found under salt stress, which is in accordance with the earlier results in wheat
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
(Sun et al. 2016). In addition, Pn was decreased by the nano-ZnO priming in wheat plants under normal condition. However, when exposed to salt stress, the nano-ZnO primed plants had significantly higher Pn than the non-primed plants. Also, higher gs and Tr were found in nano-ZnO primed plants, compared with the non-primed plants. This indicated that early nano-ZnO priming benefited the photosynthetic carbon assimilation in wheat plants exposed to subsequent salt stress. It should be noted that the nano-ZnO priming showed no significant effect on chlorophyll concentration under both normal and salt conditions. It has been reported that the concentrations of chlorophyll a and b and carotenoids were significantly increased by seed priming with ZnO nanoparticles in lupine leaves (Abdel Latef et al. 2016). Also, the high level of nano-ZnO (200-300 mg L-1) significantly reduced the chlorophyll concentration, while the carotenoids concentration was increased with nano-ZnO treatment (Wang et al. 2015). Here, the less decrease of Pn caused by nano-ZnO priming under salt stress is not due to the changes in chlorophyll concentration. This can be ascribed to that the effects of nano-ZnO on chlorophyll concentration may be dose-dependent.
The photosynthetic electron transport system links the light energy absorption of PS to
energy consumption of metabolic sinks, which is very sensitive to salt stress (Kalaji et al. 2011). The direct effects of nanoparticles in chloroplast thylakoids has been reported in wheat, indicating that the photosynthetic electron transport system could be affected by the nanoparticle application (Rastogi et al. 2019). In the present study, the nano-ZnO primed wheat plants had higher Fv/Fm than the non-primed plants under salt stress. This illuminated that the quantum yield of the PSII of wheat leaves under salt stress is enhanced by the nano-ZnO priming. The efficiency of light reactions, which is indicated by φPo (Chen et al. 2011), was also higher in the primed plants than that in non-primed plants under salt stress. However, the efficiency balance of the dark reactions after QA (ψEo) in ZnO+S plants was lower, in relation to S plants. It suggested that the probability that a trapped exciton moves an electron into the electron transport chain beyond QA- was larger in S plants than in ZnO+S
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
plants. The φEo indicates the maximum quantum yield for electron transport beyond QA, and it also reveals the quantum yield for PS II electron transport (ET); while φRo indicates the quantum yield for reduction of end electron acceptors at the PSI acceptor side (RE) (Chen et al. 2014). In this study, these two parameters were similar in the primed and non-primed plants under salt stress, indicating that these two processes were not affected by nano-ZnO priming.
The output of the leaf model of phenomenological energy fluxes (per CS) showed
different changes of electron transport process in response to nano-ZnO priming and subsequent salt stress. The energy absorbed per excited cross-section (ABS/CSm) was significantly reduced by salt stress, whereas there was no significant difference between ZnO+S and C. This suggested that the energy absorption flux was not affected by salt stress in nano-ZnO primed plants. In addition, the trapped energy flux (TRo/CSm) and electron transport flux (ETo/CSm) were both enhanced in primed plants under salt stress, in relation to non-primed plants, indicating that the nano-ZnO primed plants possessed a higher electron transport efficiency than non-primed plants under salt stress. Furthermore, it was also observed that the density of active RCs in PSII and PS I acceptor per CS in primed plants was higher than that in non-primed plants, which benefited the electron transport efficiency. At the same time, nano-ZnO priming decreased the probability that an electron is transported from the reduced intersystem electron acceptors to the final electron acceptors of PS I (Chen et al. 2011). It should be also noted that the non-photochemical quenching (DIo/CSm) was promoted by the nano-ZnO priming in wheat plants exposed to salt stress. It suggested that the higher non-photochemical quenching in primed plants is helpful for maintaining the thermo-stability of PS II under salt stress. The quantum yield of PS II photochemistry, which is indicated by ФII, was enhanced by the nano-ZnO priming under salt stress. However, the quantum yield of non-photochemical quenching (ФNPQ) was higher in non-primed plants than that in primed plants under salt stress; however, the quantum yield of other unregulated
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt
(non-photochemical) losses (ФNO) was not affected by the nano-ZnO priming.
The primary carbohydrate metabolism is important for plant growth and development,
which are also highly sensitive to the environmental changes (Botticella et al. 2018). The UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (UGPase) plays a key role in cell wall biosynthesis (Jammer et al. 2015). Here, the UGPase activity was similar between S and ZnO+S plants, which indicated that the re-synthesis of sucrose was not affected by nano-ZnO priming. As one of the key enzymes involved in starch biosynthesis, the activity of phosphoglucomutase (PGM) was higher in primed plants than non-primed plants under salt stress. An increase in PGM activity was also found in primed plants under normal condition, compared with non-primed plants. Under normal condition, the activity of phosphoglucoisomerase (PGI) was also increased by nano-ZnO priming. Interestingly, the PGI activity was lower in primed plants than non-primed plants under salt stress. This showed that reversible conversion of fructose-6-phosphate (F6P) to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) was significantly affected by nano-ZnO priming. The glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PDH) is an important enzyme in oxidative pentose phosphate pathway (Sergeeva and Vreugdenhil. 2002; Jammer et al. 2015). In the present study, the activity of G6PDH was not affected by either nano-ZnO priming or salt stress. Invertase enzymes include cell wall invertase (cwInv), vacuolar invertase (vacInv) and cytoplasmic invertase (cytInv), their activities are closely related to plant growth, senescence and salt tolerance (Fukushima et al. 2001; Roitsch and González 2004). Here, the activities of vacInv and cytInv were significantly depressed by salt stress, which agrees with the results in Lupinusalbus L. (Fernandes et al. 2004). The nano-ZnO priming enhanced the cytInv activity of wheat plants under salt stress, which also benefited the sucrose biosynthesis in leaves under salt stress. In consistent with this, it was found that nano-ZnO primed plants had significantly higher TSS concentration in leaf, compared with the non-primed plants under salt stress. The enhanced levels of osmolytes has been well documented to be closely associated with the increased salt tolerance (Ahmad et al. 2016).
Ac ce
pte d M
an us
cri pt

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In conclusion, the nano-ZnO priming reduced Na concentration and maintained a better
leaf water potential in wheat under salt stress. Compared with non-primed plants, the nano-ZnO primed plants possessed more effective oxygen scavenging system as exemplified by the enhanced activities of SOD, APX and CAT, leading to a better maintenance in homeostasis of ROS production under salt stress. This also benefited the tolerance of photosynthetic apparatus to subsequent salt stress, showing enhanced trapped energy flux and electron transport flux. In addition, the nano-ZnO priming increased the activities of phosphoglucomutase and cytoplasmic invertase, which promoted the sucrose biosynthesis in leaves under salt stress. It suggested that the early nano-ZnO priming improved the tolerance of wheat plants to the subsequent salt stress.

sections.heading: Figure legends
sections.text:
Figure 1. Concentration of Na and leaf water potential (Ψl) in the last fully expanded leaf in
wheat as affected by nano-ZnO priming and salt stress. C, control; S, salt stress; ZnO,
nano-ZnO priming; and ZnO+S, nano-ZnO priming+salt stress. Data represent the mean ± SE
of three replicates. Different letters indicate significant differences (p < 0.05).
Figure 2. Concentration of H2O2 and activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD), ascorbate
peroxidase (APX) and catalase (CAT) of the last fully expanded leaf in wheat as affected by
nano-ZnO priming and salt stress. C, control; S, salt stress; ZnO, nano-ZnO priming; and
ZnO+S, nano-ZnO priming+salt stress. Data represent the mean ± SE of three replicates.
Different letters indicate significant differences (p < 0.05).
Figure 3. Net photosynthetic rate (Pn), chlorophyll concentration (SPAD value), stomatal
conductance (gs) and transpiration rate (Tr) of the last fully expanded leaf in wheat as affected
by nano-ZnO priming and salt stress. C, control; S, salt stress; ZnO, nano-ZnO priming; and
ZnO+S, nano-ZnO priming+salt stress. Data represent the mean ± SE of three replicates.
Different letters indicate significant differences (p < 0.05).
Figure 4. Fluorescence transient Chl a parameters deduced from analysis of the JIP-test of
wheat as affected by nano-ZnO priming and salt stress. Abbreviations of treatments are
explained in Figure 1. Explanations of these parameters are shown in Table 1.
Figure 5. Energy pipeline leaf model of phenomenological fluxes (per cross-section, CS) of
the flag leaf in wheat as affected by nano-ZnO priming and salt stress. Abbreviations of
treatments are explained in Figure 1. Each relative value is drawn by the width of the
corresponding arrow, standing for a parameter. Empty and full black circles indicate,
respectively, the percentage of active (QA reducing) and non-active (non QA reducing)

Figure 7. Activities of enzymes involved in primary carbohydrate metabolism in the last fully

cytInv, cytoplasmic invertase; vacInv, vacuolar invertase; and cwInv, cell wall invertase. Data

indicate significant differences (p < 0.05).

referenceMentions.context: Soil salinity is a critical problem, influencing more than 800 million hectares of land in the world, and it accounts for more than 6% of the global land mass (Munns and Tester 2008).
Ac ce pte d M an us cri pt yield loss exceeds 60% due to soil salinity in wheat (El-Hendawy et al. 2017).

The salt-induced loss of grain yield is related to the adverse effects of excess salts on photosynthesis, carbohydrate metabolism and plant water status (Kerepesi et al. 1998; Mehta et al. 2010; Sun et al. 2016).

The salt-induced loss of grain yield is related to the adverse effects of excess salts on photosynthesis, carbohydrate metabolism and plant water status (Kerepesi et al. 1998; Mehta et al. 2010; Sun et al. 2016).

The salt-induced loss of grain yield is related to the adverse effects of excess salts on photosynthesis, carbohydrate metabolism and plant water status (Kerepesi et al. 1998; Mehta et al. 2010; Sun et al. 2016).
Photosynthesis is the primary metabolic sink to support plant growth, converting light energy into ATP and redox equivalents (Brestic et al. 2012; Zivcak et al. 2013; Brestic et al. 2014).
Photosynthesis is the primary metabolic sink to support plant growth, converting light energy into ATP and redox equivalents (Brestic et al. 2012; Zivcak et al. 2013; Brestic et al. 2014).
Photosynthesis is the primary metabolic sink to support plant growth, converting light energy into ATP and redox equivalents (Brestic et al. 2012; Zivcak et al. 2013; Brestic et al. 2014).
High salt results in modulations in expression of photosynthetic proteins in chloroplasts, depressing functioning of the photosystems (PS) (Zhao et al. 2013).

The processes of light energy trapping by the antenna of PS I and PS II and charge separation in reaction centres (RCs) are easily disturbed by salt stress, since the chlorophyll antenna complexes trap more energy than the capacity of biochemical procession in RCs, hence leading to accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Kaur et al. 2018).
It has been well documented that an early exposure to a moderate stressor can result in a higher tolerance to the subsequent stress in various plant species (Bruce et al. 2007; Wang et al. 2017).
It has been well documented that an early exposure to a moderate stressor can result in a higher tolerance to the subsequent stress in various plant species (Bruce et al. 2007; Wang et al. 2017).
Also, the pretreatment with a low level of NaCl can induce a higher salt tolerance, which is referred to as salt acclimation (Janda et al. 2016; Wang et al. 2017).
Also, the pretreatment with a low level of NaCl can induce a higher salt tolerance, which is referred to as salt acclimation (Janda et al. 2016; Wang et al. 2017).

Our previous study showed that the salt acclimation induced salt tolerance in wheat by driving the antioxidant systems to protect photosynthetic electron transport and maintaining a better water status (Wang et al. 2017).
Nanoparticles (NPs) is a kind of particulate nanomaterial with at least one dimension in the nanoscale (1-100 nm) (Wang et al. 2015).

Some kinds of NPs can be easily uptaken, transported, and accumulated in plant organs, which regulate the physiological and biochemical processes, hence affecting plant growth and development, such as silicon nanoparticle and magnesium nanoparticle (Rastogi et al. 2017).
Ac ce pte d M an us cri pt determined by their size, reactivity, chemical structure and surface coating (Tripathi et al. 2017b).
As metal ions, NPs react with sulfhydryl and carboxyl groups of proteins, and thus alter the activities of enzymes (Shaw et al. 2014).
However, both positive and negative influences of nano-ZnO on plant growth have been found in several plant species (Du et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Abdel Latef et al. 2016).
However, both positive and negative influences of nano-ZnO on plant growth have been found in several plant species (Du et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Abdel Latef et al. 2016).
The impact of nano-ZnO on plant depends its size, concentration, and exposure methodology (Rastogi et al. 2017).
For instance, the exposure to nano-ZnO (1000 mg L) caused oxidative stress and significantly reduced the root length at early growing stages in rice (Boonyanitipong et al. 2011).
Nano-ZnO exposure inhibited activities of the ascorbate-glutathione cycle (AsA-GSH), hence increasing H2O2 accumulation and lipid peroxidation (Tripathi et al. 2017a).
Fast chlorophyll a fluorescence induction curve can be used to test the photosynthetic electron transport as influenced by salt stress (Kalaji et al. 2018).
The activities of APX and SOD in leaves were measured following our previous methods (Tan et al. 2008).
Catalase (CAT) activity was determined spectrophotometrically following H2O2 consumption at 240 nm (Bailly et al. 1996).

The MultispeQ is developed for the rapid capture fluorescence parameters during steady-state illumination using a procedure that obviates the need for extensive pre-acclimation to the leaf chamber light conditions (Kuhlgert et al. 2016).

The UDP-glucose pyrophorylase (UGPase), glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PDH), phosphoglucomutase (PGM) and phosphoglucoisomerase (PGI) was assessed in the endpoint assays, while the invertases (cytoplasmic invertase; vacuolar invertase and cell wall invertase) was determined in kinetic enzyme assays (Gasperl et al. 2015; Jammer et al. 2015).

The UDP-glucose pyrophorylase (UGPase), glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PDH), phosphoglucomutase (PGM) and phosphoglucoisomerase (PGI) was assessed in the endpoint assays, while the invertases (cytoplasmic invertase; vacuolar invertase and cell wall invertase) was determined in kinetic enzyme assays (Gasperl et al. 2015; Jammer et al. 2015).
Ac ce pte d M an us cri pt within the linear range of substrate conversion and expressed in nkatmgprotein (Jammer et al. 2015).
High salt concentrations in soil cause a decrease in water potential, which affects water availability (Jakab et al. 2005).
Ac ce pte d M an us cri pt absorption of roots and changes leaf water status in wheat (Rahnama et al. 2010).
In scavenging ROS, SOD catalyzes the disproportionation of singlet oxygen ((1)O2) generated from chloroplast electron transport chains and produces H2O2 (Keunen et al. 2013).
Then CAT decomposes H2O2 to H2O and O2, together with APX (Keunen et al. 2013).
Also, the high level of nano-ZnO (200-300 mg L) significantly reduced the chlorophyll concentration, while the carotenoids concentration was increased with nano-ZnO treatment (Wang et al. 2015).
The photosynthetic electron transport system links the light energy absorption of PS to energy consumption of metabolic sinks, which is very sensitive to salt stress (Kalaji et al. 2011).

The direct effects of nanoparticles in chloroplast thylakoids has been reported in wheat, indicating that the photosynthetic electron transport system could be affected by the nanoparticle application (Rastogi et al. 2019).
The efficiency of light reactions, which is indicated by φPo (Chen et al. 2011), was also higher in the primed plants than that in non-primed plants under salt stress.

The φEo indicates the maximum quantum yield for electron transport beyond QA, and it also reveals the quantum yield for PS II electron transport (ET); while φRo indicates the quantum yield for reduction of end electron acceptors at the PSI acceptor side (RE) (Chen et al. 2014).

At the same time, nano-ZnO priming decreased the probability that an electron is transported from the reduced intersystem electron acceptors to the final electron acceptors of PS I (Chen et al. 2011).
The UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (UGPase) plays a key role in cell wall biosynthesis (Jammer et al. 2015).
The glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PDH) is an important enzyme in oxidative pentose phosphate pathway (Sergeeva and Vreugdenhil. 2002; Jammer et al. 2015).

Invertase enzymes include cell wall invertase (cwInv), vacuolar invertase (vacInv) and cytoplasmic invertase (cytInv), their activities are closely related to plant growth, senescence and salt tolerance (Fukushima et al. 2001; Roitsch and González 2004).
